Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as the foreman called out, “End of shift! Don’t forget to sweep your area.” My boots crunched over scattered debris—nails, wood chips, dust. I knew the rules: leave your spot clean, or risk a warning. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Polls close in 30 minutes.” I’d promised myself I’d vote this year, no matter what. I rushed to the polling station, still in my work clothes, dust clinging to my jeans. The line snaked out the door. An official called, “A–M last names, please move to the new line!” My last name started with B. The new line looked longer, but the official’s voice was firm. I hesitated, glancing at the clock, thinking about the mess I’d left behind at the site and the rules I was supposed to follow here. My mind raced—should I stick to my work ethic and go back to clean, or follow the voting instructions and risk being late for both? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
